scene.name: intro
scene.option: What do you think about when you're playing?

scene.name: evaluation
scene.line: Oh, hm. I don't think I understand your question.
scene.option: I just don't know how to tell if it was good or not.
I was just pressing buttons, but you're like a theremin scientist ...

scene.name: good-or-not
scene.line: Oh, right. Evaluation. Good music and bad music.
I don't like to think about my work that way. Sometimes it's difficult not to; of course it's natural to want your art to be "good," even if you don't know what that means, but ...

scene.name: theremin-scientist
scene.line: A scientist? Oh no. Ha ha.
But ... like a scientist, I experiment. `Unlike` a scientist, I have no hypothesis.

scene.name: outcomes
scene.line: I try not to be attached to outcomes. Does that make sense? My violin teacher used to tell me to play like a tourist: "Act as though you've never been there before."

scene.name: subject
scene.line: I try not to think about anything at all. My violin teacher used to say, "Why make art? To quiet the mind."
Still ... I'm not very good at it. Quieting my mind.
When I'm playing this piece, I'm usually thinking of my uncle, Andrius. I never knew him when I was a child, except in postcards, but we became very close over the last few years.

He was a collector of sounds. Like you! He traveled and recorded the songs of birds, of rivers, of city traffic, of crooked, moonlit highways. He sold his sounds by mail-order to movie studios and private collectors.
They ended up in films and television shows, mostly, dislocated and reattached to other images.
So. No quiet in this mind, I'm sorry to say.

scene.name: goodbye
scene.line: I hope you'll continue making tapes, Ezra. I'm sure there are many more people who would enjoy listening to them, on this river and elsewhere.
